title: Scrap generous tax breaks for final salary pensions
text:
Tip : Use comma (,) to separate multiple quotes. Learn more... 
Mon, Jul 6, 2015, 20:46 BST - UK Markets closed Scrap generous tax breaks for final salary pensions By Richard Dyson | Telegraph – 10 hours ago 
The Budget should address this one tax unfairness, if nothing else, says Richard Dyson 
George Osborne’s previous budgets have surprised, even dazzled, with the breadth of their reform. 
In his first Conservative Budget on Wednesday he may surprise again: I hope so, in particular by simplifying our crushingly byzantine personal tax regime. 
But even if he does little or nothing not already trailed in terms of cutting personal tax, or reducing its complexity, there is one unfairness in the tax system he should address above others. And ironing it out could cost the Exchequer nothing. 
It’s the unfairly beneficial taxation of “final salary” type pensions, enjoyed among others by civil servants and MPs themselves, compared with the more common “money purchase” pensions. 
• The Chancellor must stun us with a radical tax-cutting Budget 
• What to expect at the 'Emergency Budget' 
Under current arrangements someone with a final salary-type pension could start their retirement on an income of £50,000. They could do so and escape paying any tax under the pension “lifetime allowance”. 
The most that a money purchase saver could hope to start their retirement on, before being hit with the 55pc tax resulting from the lifetime allowance, is around £28,600 on a like-for-like basis. 
That difference is huge and iniquitous. 
It arises from the way the value of a pension is calculated for the purposes of applying the lifetime cap. 
If you are in a final salary-type scheme your promised annual pension at the start of retirement is simply multiplied by 20. Any lump sum you choose to take is added on top. From April 2016, the lifetime allowance is £1m. Above that, tax is applied of up to 55pc. 
If you are a money purchase saver the process is entirely different. You are building up the pot as you work. The pot is what is measured for the purposes of taxation. 
But what benefits can you get from a pot worth £1m? 
If you were to buy an annuity the most directly comparable outcome to the benefits promised by a final salary pension your £1m would buy an annuity where the starting income was just £28,600. That annuity, like the final salary arrangement, would also offer inflation-linking and a spouse’s benefit on the pensioner’s death. 
• 'My pension is over the lifetime allowance. Do I pay a tax charge as well as income tax?' 
• The tables that reveal your tax bill on pension withdrawals 
To get anything like the £50,000 starting pension enjoyed by the final salary saver, you’d need a £1.6m pot and be exposed to a tax bill running into several hundred thousands pounds. 
The lifetime allowance is itself, as I’ve argued here before, an ill-judged tax that hurts younger savers and those who invest successfully. 
But this unequal way in which it is applied is another order of unfairness altogether. 
It wouldn’t take someone in the Treasury long to devise a better way of valuing final salary-type pensions for the purpose of this cap, taking into account comparable annuity rates and other factors. And yes, if applied today it would mean those savers with final salary schemes would pay more tax or get smaller benefits before tax was due. 
There’s a misjudged tax, and there’s a misjudged tax unfairly applied. At least let’s deal with the latter. 
- richard.dyson@telegraph.co.uk
